Summary: All test indicators are within the normal range, suggesting no significant abnormalities in the current peripheral blood picture, with no signs indicating infection, inflammation, allergy, or other significant abnormalities in the hematopoietic system.
Summary_1: No significant abnormalities in peripheral blood picture
Interpretation: All indicators (including total white blood cell count, various white blood cell subsets, etc.) are within the normal range, indicating that the body's immune status and hematopoietic system function are currently stable, with no significant stress response or pathological changes observed. If the patient has no related symptoms, the current test results can be considered to have no significant clinical significance.

NST#_1: Elevated immature neutrophils (NST#) usually indicate stimulation of the bone marrow hematopoietic system or the presence of inflammation, infection, etc., commonly seen in stress responses, infections (especially bacterial infections), or certain hematological diseases.
Summary: Test results show elevated NST# (immature neutrophils), while other blood cell parameters are within normal range. This result suggests possible mild reactive bone marrow hyperplasia, commonly seen in the early stages of inflammation or infection, but without significant elevation in total white blood cell count or other blood cell abnormalities. Further evaluation is needed in conjunction with clinical symptoms and other laboratory tests.
Summary_1: Possible mild reactive bone marrow hyperplasia, cannot rule out early infection.
Interpretation: Elevated NST# is usually related to the bone marrow's response to infection, inflammation, or other stress states. In the absence of significant WBC and NEU elevation, isolated NST# elevation may suggest early infection or inflammatory response, especially in the initial stage of bacterial infection, before the bone marrow has caused a significant increase in mature neutrophil count. Attention should be paid to the source of infection, and comprehensive judgment should be made in conjunction with CRP, PCT, clinical manifestations, etc.
Possible Disease 1_2: Elevated NST# suggests bone marrow response to infection, common in early bacterial infection, especially when local infection has not yet caused significant WBC elevation.
Possible Disease 2_2: Non-infectious stress (such as surgery, trauma, severe illness) may also cause elevated NST#, but usually accompanied by other blood picture changes.
Possible Disease 3_2: Elevated NST# can also be seen in certain myeloproliferative disorders or during recovery from aplastic anemia, but requires more hematological evidence for support.

NSH#: Seen in inflammatory recovery phase, use of antimetabolite drugs, nutritional megaloblastic anemia, pernicious anemia. Transient nuclear right shift during inflammatory recovery is a normal phenomenon.
NSH#_1: Nuclear right shift is defined when neutrophils with 5 or more nuclear lobes exceed 3%.
Summary: Test results show elevated NSH#, while other blood cell classification indicators are within normal range, suggesting possible mild reactive bone marrow hyperplasia or immature neutrophil release due to infection. Further evaluation is needed in conjunction with clinical manifestations.
Summary_1: Possible mild reactive bone marrow hyperplasia/infection.
Interpretation: Elevated NSH# (immature neutrophils) usually indicates accelerated release of incompletely mature granulocytes from the bone marrow into peripheral blood under stress, commonly seen in acute infections (such as bacterial infections) or inflammatory responses. In the absence of abnormalities in other white blood cell counts (WBC) or other classified cells, this change may represent a mild or early infectious process, or compensatory bone marrow hyperplasia caused by local inflammation. It is recommended to make a comprehensive judgment based on the patient's clinical symptoms (such as fever, site of infection) and other laboratory tests (such as C-reactive protein, absolute neutrophil count, etc.).
Possible Disease 1_2: Elevated NSH# is seen in inflammatory recovery phase, use of antimetabolite drugs, nutritional megaloblastic anemia, pernicious anemia. Transient nuclear right shift during inflammatory recovery is a normal phenomenon.
Possible Disease 2_2: Compensatory release of immature cells from the bone marrow under stimulation of inflammation or infection, with elevated NSH# being one of the typical manifestations.
Possible Disease 3_2: Small-scale inflammation or trauma may cause local immune activation and mild bone marrow reaction, but usually not accompanied by significant NSH# elevation.

ALY#: Elevated ALY# suggests consideration of viral infectious diseases (such as infectious mononucleosis, viral pneumonia, viral hepatitis, mumps, chickenpox, cytomegalovirus infection), pertussis, brucellosis, syphilis, toxoplasmosis infection, drug reactions, lymphocytic leukemia, etc.
ALY#_1: Generally, reactive lymphocytes in viral infections are <5%, while in infectious mononucleosis, reactive lymphocytes often exceed 10%.
Summary: Elevated ALY# suggests consideration of viral infectious diseases (such as infectious mononucleosis, viral pneumonia, viral hepatitis, mumps, chickenpox, cytomegalovirus infection), pertussis, brucellosis, syphilis, toxoplasmosis infection, drug reactions, lymphocytic leukemia, etc. However, other blood cell indicators (WBC, NEU, LYM, EOS, MON, etc.) are normal, suggesting no significant infection or hematological abnormalities are currently observed. Further evaluation is needed in conjunction with clinical background.
Summary_1: Possible viral infection/pertussis, brucellosis, or syphilis.
Interpretation: Elevated ALY# is usually related to the compensatory response of the bone marrow to anemia, hemolysis, or chronic inflammation. Since other white blood cell classification indicators (such as neutrophils, lymphocytes, etc.) show no significant abnormalities, it suggests that acute infection or immune system disorder is not currently present. This abnormality may reflect the bone marrow's response to some underlying stimulus, such as recent recovery from iron deficiency anemia, chronic inflammatory stimulation, or mild hemolysis. Comprehensive judgment should be made in conjunction with the patient's symptoms, signs, and other laboratory tests (such as hemoglobin, reticulocyte count, etc.).
Possible Disease 1_2: Elevated ALY# may suggest reactive hyperplasia of the bone marrow in response to chronic inflammation, but without significant white blood cell classification abnormalities.
Possible Disease 2_2: Elevated ALY# is common during compensatory erythroid hyperplasia in anemia recovery, and needs to be judged in conjunction with hemoglobin levels.
Possible Disease 3_2: Elevated ALY# may be related to increased red blood cell destruction and compensatory bone marrow production, but requires further support from other hemolysis indicators such as indirect bilirubin, reticulocyte count, etc.
